title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 12
author: Various
snippet: A sober man may pass the Tarras a hundredtimes, and see nought; but, after a Langholm hiring-day, or a July fair,if a man hae taen twa-three cheerers forbye common, he's maist sure tosee the WHITE LEDDY O' TARRAS!

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 12
author: Various
snippet: A sober man may pass the Tarras a hundredtimes, and see nought; but, after a Langholm hiring-day, or a July fair,if a man hae taen twa-three cheerers forbye common, he's maist sure tosee the WHITE LEDDY O' TARRAS!

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: PatPagan tells me it won't come off; so we'll e'en see if the Tarras waterwinna wash it oot"--pulling the sword out of the hands of the grimsergeant, and swinging it backwards and forwards in the adjoining pool.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Gilbert had been compelled tobetake him to the mountain passes on this account, and was supposed tohave taken up his abode in what was called "Fox Den," on the water ofTarras.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Earls of Glencairn, Crawford, Dundonald, and Tarras, with several otherpersons of consideration, encouraged the rising of the Presbyterians, who, hastilyassuming arms, appeared in different parts of the country, in open opposition tothe government.
